clinical_study.brief_title: Optimal Location of Nerve Block to Minimize Perioperative Opioid Administration in ACL Surgery: Comparing True Adductor Canal to Proximal Block
clinical_study.official_title: Optimal Location of Nerve Block to Minimize Perioperative Opioid Administration in ACL Surgery: Comparing True Adductor Canal to Proximal Block

lead_sponsor.agency: New York University School of Medicine

clinical_study.source: New York University School of Medicine

brief_summary.textblock:
This is a prospective, randomized, single blinded trial involving human subjects. The goal of this study is to determine an optimal location (proximal or distal) for the nerve block and whether it will make a difference in how much opioid the patient will receive during and after surgery. Ultrasound will identify the adductor canal and the proximal end of the adductor canal/apex of the femoral triangle to determine the location of the blocks.
Their will be two randomized groups: 1. ACB within true AC with bupivacaine 0.5% 20cc2. ACB proximal to true AC with bupivacaine 0.5% 20cc

primary_outcome.measure: Total opioid consumption intraop measured by amount of morphine administered
Total opioid consumption postop by amount of morphine administered

arm_group.arm_group_label: ACB within true AC with bupivacaine
arm_group.description: The patients will receive an ultrasound-guided single injection adductor canal block with 20 mL of 0.5% bupivacaine

arm_group.arm_group_label: ACB proximal to true AC with bupivacaine
arm_group.description: The patients will receive an ultrasound-guided single injection femoral triangle block with 20 mL of 0.5% bupivacaine

intervention.intervention_name: ACB within true AC with bupivacaine 0.5% 20cc
intervention.description: The adductor canal block (ACB) is more commonly being used to provide post-operative analgesia since it provides a sensory block with minimal motor block.
